title: Scientists reveal the best and worst dance moves for women
text: Share 96 shares Women who swing their hips a lot when dancing, such as Beyonce (pictured left) had their moves rated higher than those who kept them still, such as Ann Widdecombe (pictured right) 'Hip swing is a very feminine trait, so by swinging your hips more you are displaying your femininity. 'By moving your arms and legs asymmetrically you are displaying high level motor control and lack of neurological dysfunction. 'If you can move your limbs independently, slightly out of phase and with different gestures and flourishes then you are showing of a high level of motor control and also perhaps flair, intelligence and creativity.' The researchers used 3D motion-capture technology to record the dance moves of 39 women as they each boogied to a basic drum beat. Pictured on the left is an example of a poor dance move as it's symmetrical. Researchers argue that swaying your hips and moving your arms in an asymmetric fashion could make you more of a success on the dancefloor Research has found that moving your arms and thighs symmetrically and keeping your hips still make you a poorly rated dancer (a), while shifting your arms asymmetrically (b) and moving your hips a lot makes you a good dancer THE BEST DANCE MOVES FOR MEN The team have looked at the best and worst male dance moves previously, too. They found that the top rated male dancers have plenty of upper body movement incorporated into their moves. Male physical strength is accurately conveyed by dancing, so stronger men make better dancers, which could be an evolutionary advantage to women looking for a mate. The authors took the movements made by the women and rendered them onto 3D avatars. 'If you ask people to rate video clips of people dancing they can be biased by their physical appearance, body size, skin colour, clothing etc,' Dr Neave told MailOnline. 'So we convert all of our dancers into featureless avatars so that we know our raters can only be judging someone on how they move.' Fifty seven men and 143 women were then asked to rate the dancing ability of each of the 39 avatars based on a 15 second section of video footage. The authors compared the ratings to measurements of the dancers' moves. The popular 'dabbing' dance move uses asymmetric arms movements, which according to the researchers, is a good thing The motion capture technology registered how much the best and worst dancers moved each limb and placed the data on a graph. In this graph, a) shows arm movements, b) shows hip movements, and c) shows thigh movements of the five best and five worst dancers The team have looked at the best and worst male dance moves previously, too. They found that the top rated male dancers have plenty of upper body movement incorporated into their moves. Male physical strength is accurately conveyed by dancing, so stronger men make better dancers, which could be an evolutionary advantage to women looking for a mate. And the researchers have lofty ambitions for the future of movement studies. 'At present the scientific understanding of human body movements and how they relate to things like attractiveness, health, reproductive status and pathology are in their infancy,' Dr Neave told MailOnline. 'We are trying to develop accurate methods and statistical techniques to discriminate between movements that are perceived to be "good" in dancing and walking. 'We can then apply those techniques to other lines of enquiry â€“ i.e. "Can you detect threat in the way someone moves?" "Can you detect mental illness or neurodegenerative diseases before some shows the symptoms?" etc.' The research is published this week in Nature . Read more: Share or comment on this article 96
